column26: The council advises: Please see our open letter to the Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, sent shortly after the Budget was passed, for our concerns about adult social care funding: https://www.islington.media/news/an-open-letter-to-steve-barclay-mp-secretary-of-state-for-health-and-social-care
The shortfall figure assumes that the additional social care government grant ceases in 2025/26. The figure on the council tax raise excludes a 0.18% increase of Garden Square special expenses.

The Council advises: Leicestershire is the lowest funded county in the country. An example is that someone living in a £1m Westminster property pays £1,000 in Council Tax, compared to someone paying £2,500 in a £375,000 property in Coalville in Leicestershire.

column25: Unable to provide shortfall figure. The council advises: we do predict a shortfall in 2025/26. The MTFP is currently being reviewed, so the level of the shortfall not clear at this stage. The shortfall for 2024/25 is around £6.5m.

Unable to provide shortfall figure. The council advises: Central government funding, through either the national NNDR funding system, or revenue grants makes up broadly two thirds of Newham Council’s net budget. The other third is made up of council tax, and central government determine a limit to any % increase that might be applied to council tax. At the time of writing central government has not made any meaningful announcements on any of these funding streams, so although a funding gap is expected, we are therefore not able to accurately plan for either the 2024/25 or 2025/26 financial year

column12: Some changes to savings proposals were announced in the meeting itself and were reflected in the final budget proposal considered by Council on 28th February 2023

column1: Newry, Mourne and Down District Council
column25: Unable to provide shortfall figure. The council advises: the Council’s four year rates estimate process is to commence in line with the new sitting Council from 1 June 2023. Work will begin at the first Finance Working Group meeting once Membership has been determined.

The council advises: the Council has a net movement in reserves of £6.35million, however the reserves have not been used to balance the budget – reserves of £2.47m have been used to fund planned time-limited expenditure costs using earmarked reserves. Use of £3.88m of reserves is for the adjustment in respect of Business Rates grants under S31 of the Local Government Finance Act 2008 received in 2022-23, which is budgeted to be drawn down in 2023-24 to fund the Business Rates Collection Fund deficit. The is a lag in the timing between when the grant is received and the impact on the Collection Fund which is managed through the reserves to transfer the resources across financial years (this is the same for all Councils in receipt of BR grant).
column26: The council advises: the shortfall figure makes assumptions regarding potential changes in the national funding regime for 2025/26 including Business Rates reset. However, this is yet to be confirmed.

column26: The council advises: the shortfall figure assumes a Business Rates Reset in 2025/26, "which may not happen and therefore the funding shortfall would be significantly less".
Giving the worst-case scenario: potential budget gap of between £35m and £109m for 2025/26

The council advises: Assuming savings plans for 2023/24 are fully achieved at the level set out at Q3 above, the target for 2024/25 is then £11,941,057. The MTFS assumes that savings planned for each year are fully achieved on an ongoing basis (although planning can be flexed to accommodate under or over achievement).

The council advises: the Council’s net revenue budget for 2023/24 is £143m, of which £32m is funded by the capitalisation direction. This is a 62% reduction in the capitalisation direction from 2022/23, which demonstrates the excellent progress the Council is making in addressing its historical issues. Council meeting in March. £17m shortfall in 2025/26, cumulative capitalisation/shortfall of £339m, although these figures remain subject to change as new information, analysis and decisions come to light. £17m shortfall in 2025/26, cumulative capitalisation/shortfall of £339m, although these figures remain subject to change as new information, analysis and decisions come to light. Reserves: No, but Slough is reliant on a capitalisation direction to balance the budget. In 2023/24 this amounts to c£32m.
Giving the worst-case scenario: potential budget gap of between £7.51m and £22.209m. Net revenue includes 96.349m passed to Health & Social CarePartnership.
This council faces "a financial situation of an extremely serious nature". It balances this year's budget with government support.

The council advises: tn terms of our Medium-Term Resource Plan, (for the next four years), we are currently reviewing this with the intention to present it to Cabinet in July 2023 as part of the 2022/2023 budget out-turn report. This document will detail our anticipated future year funding gap.
